(GATE CSE 2005)

questions.question:
Let p,q,r and s be four primitive statements. Consider the following arguments:

\( egin{array}{l} P:[( eg p \vee q) \wedge(r ightarrow s) \wedge(p \vee r)] ightarrow( eg s ightarrow q) \ Q:[( eg p \wedge q) \wedge[q ightarrow(p ightarrow r)]] ightarrow eg r \ R:[[(q \wedge r) ightarrow p] \wedge( eg q \vee p)] ightarrow r \ S:[p \wedge(p ightarrow r) \wedge(q \vee eg r)] ightarrow q \end{array}\)

Which of the above arguments are valid?

(GATE IT 2004)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let a(x, y), b(x, y,) and c(x, y) be three statements with variables x and y chosen from some universe. Consider the following statement:
\(\qquad(\exists x)(\forall y)[(a(x, y) \wedge b(x, y)) \wedge \neg c(x, y)]\)
Which one of the following is its equivalent?

(GATE IT 2004)
options:
A.

\((\forall x)(\exists y)[(a(x, y) \vee b(x, y)) \to c(x, y)]\)

B.

\((\exists x)(\forall y)[(a(x, y) \vee b(x, y)) \wedge\neg c(x, y)]\)

C.

\(\neg (\forall x)(\exists y)[(a(x, y) \wedge b(x, y)) \to c(x, y)]\)

D.

\(\neg (\forall x)(\exists y)[(a(x, y) \vee b(x, y)) \to c(x, y)]\)
questions.correct_answer:
C.

\(\neg (\forall x)(\exists y)[(a(x, y) \wedge b(x, y)) \to c(x, y)]\)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Identify the correct translation into logical notation of the following assertion.

Some boys in the class are taller than all the girls

Note: taller (x, y) is true if x is taller than y.

(GATE CSE 2004)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
the following resolution rule is used in logic programming:
Derive clause(P \(\vee\) Q) from clauses (P \(\vee\) R),(Q \(\vee \neg\) JR)
Which of the following statements related to this rule is FASLE?

(GATE CSE 2003)
options:
A.

\(((P \vee R) \wedge (Q \vee \neg R)) \Rightarrow (P \vee Q)\) is logically valid

B.

\((P \vee Q) \Rightarrow ((P \vee R)\wedge (Q \vee \neg R))\) is logically valid

C.

\((P \vee Q)\) is satisfiable if and only if \((P \vee R)\wedge (Q \vee \neg R)\) is satisfiable

D.

\((P \vee Q)\Rightarrow\) FALSE if and only if both P and Q are unsatisfiable
questions.correct_answer:
B.

\((P \vee Q) \Rightarrow ((P \vee R)\wedge (Q \vee \neg R))\) is logically valid

questions.question:

\(\alpha :(\forall x)[P_{x}\leftrightarrow (\forall y)[Q_{xy}\leftrightarrow \neg Q_{yy}]]\rightarrow (\forall x)[\neg P_{x}]\)

I1: Domain : the set of natural numbers
\(P_{x}\equiv x\) is a prime number
\(Q_{xy}\equiv y\) divides x

I2; same as I1 except that \(P_{x}\equiv x\) is a composite number.

Which of the following statements is true?

questions.question:
Let (S,\(\leq\)) be a partial order with two minimal elements a and b, and a maximum element c.
Let P:S \(\rightarrow\) {True, False} be a predicate defined on S . Suppose that P(a) = True, P(b) =False and P(x) \(\Rightarrow\) p(y) for all x,y \(\in\) S satisfying x\(\leq\)y, where \(\Rightarrow\) stands for logical implication. Which of the following statements CANNOT be true?

(GATE CSE 2003)
options:
A.

P(x) =True for all x \(\in\) S such that x \(\neq\) b

B.

P(x) =False for all x \(\in\) S such that x \(\neq\) a and x \(\neq\) c

C.

P(x) =False for all x \(\in\) S such that b \(\leq\) x and x \(\neq\) c

D.

P(x) =False for all x \(\in\) S such that a \(\leq\) x and b \(\leq\) x
questions.correct_answer:
D.

P(x) =False for all x \(\in\) S such that a \(\leq\) x and b \(\leq\) x
